Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The Metabolism of Prenylated Benzoquinones through the Lens of Plant-Prokaryote Phylogenomics

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientific merit: This project aims to elucidate the architecture and evolution of the biosynthetic networks of terpenoid quinones. Far from being anecdotal compounds, prenylated quinone conjugates are key cofactors for the electron and proton transfer chains that are at the core of the bio-energy production systems on our planet. This includes photosynthesis, respiration, and chemosynthesis, just to name a few. But because quinones are present in trace quantities and in most organisms their cognate biosynthetic mutants are lethal, quinones are difficult to study and some of the most important branches of quinone metabolism are still uncharted. Where conventional biochemical and genetic approaches have hit a wall, this research makes use of a system biology alternative that combines comparative genomic inferences with in silico metabolic reconstructions, so candidate genes can be identified and experimentally tested by means of reverse genetics, enzymological studies and targeted metabolite profiling. Plants are particularly well suited for this type of integrative approach, for their genomes have been 'enriched', via numerous events of lateral gene transfer, in genes of direct bacterial and archaeal origin.

Broader impacts: This project will establish an on-line resource for both students and instructors in order to promote the learning of bioinformatics data mining nationwide. Based on active learning methods, personal assignments, and continuous evaluation, the project will teach students to get the full benefit of phylogenomics methods for their current and future research. The project will also raise awareness of vitamins nutrition through an educational package aimed at children of middle school age, for whom it highlights the importance of plant micronutrients and good dietary habits. The project will also contribute to the training of two undergraduate research assistants, one PhD student, and one postdoctoral associate in the laboratory of the PI.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The goal of the project was to elucidate how plants and cyanobacteria synthesize a class of compounds, called terpenoid quinones, that serve as vital cofactors for photosynthesis, respiration, antioxidants, and in some cases vitamins for vertebrates.

The major findings that stem from this research are:

1) The discovery of an unsuspected enzymatic step in the biosynthetic pathway of vitamin K1 (phylloquinone). We identified the corresponding genes in plants and cyanobacteria, and showed that theses genes encode type II dehydrogenases that catalyze a key reduction step that is crucial for the biological activity of vitamin K1. After reviewing our data, the International Union of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology assigned an official Enzyme Commission number to these enzymes (EC 1.6.5.12). The vitamin K biosynthetic pathway of reference databases and textbooks have been re-drawn accordingly.

2) The finding that plants are unique among living organisms in having the capacity to synthesize coenzyme Q (ubiquinone) -a vital respiratory cofactor and antioxidant molecule- from the beta-oxidative metabolism of an amino acid called phenylalanine. 

3) The finding that plants are also able to branch the biosynthesis of coenzyme Q from the catabolism of a flavonoid compound called kaempferol. This discovery represents a profound paradigm shift regarding the functional significance of flavonoids, which until now have been regarded as 'secondary metabolites' (i.e. not required for the core biological processes of an organism). Our data show that in fact the cleavage of kaempferol contributes to respiration in plants. 

4) The identification of a missing step and its cognate enzyme in the degradation pathway of the amino acids leucine, isoleucine and valine in plants.

All together our research resulted in the publications of 11 articles in top-tier peer-reviewed scientic journals of international audience. Furthermore, the project contributed to the training and career development of 7 undergraduate students, 3 graduate students, 8 postdoctoral researchers, and 1 high-school science teacher.  

Broader Impact and Outreach: Our discovery of novel steps and metabolic branch-points in the biosynthesis of plant terpenoid quinones has opened new avenues to improve crop yield and the nutritional value of plant-based food. In particular, we showed that tomato fruits that have been engineered to accumulate flavonoids contain significantly more coenzyme Q than their conventional counterparts. We have also shown that plant mutants blocked in the degradation of leucine, isoleucine, and valine -all of which are essential amino acids in the diet of humans and farm animals- accumulate these amino acids at very high level in their leaves and seeds.

In each year of the project, we ran an educational package aimed at raising awareness about healthy nutritional habits in children enrolled at the Nebraska 4-H in Lincoln, NE open house and at Talbot Elementary in Gainesville, FL. We also contributed to the 'Sunday with a Scientist' outreach program hosted at the Nebraska Museum of Natural History, where we explained to families how scientists use biotechnologies to improve the nutritional quality of plant-based food.
